author: ryg9705

author: arnetheduck
content: one mans nasty is the other mans guarantee against _broken_ hacks

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content: Just to be clear - we are going to isolate phase 0 code by having a "hard copy" so there would be no risk to break it with phase 1. I would say that's a guarrantee against mistakes in always growing code branching, which IMHO is a *broken* hack ðŸ™‚ For sure there are multiple ways to do it, but I would like to hear if anyone has more experience with the isolated approach.

author: arnetheduck
content: makes sense - what statically typed languages do is help you sort out the boundary between the two worlds at compile time, so you have fewer edge cases to worry about at runtime - which is nice - the main issue being the migration of data from phase0 to phase1 - specially in languages with good support for generics, the compile-time checks can be made pretty powerful

author: sauliusgrigaitis
content:
I'm more about the cases when compiler can't help. Static typing for sure helps to find some issues at compile-time, but that's only a relatively small part. Let's say there is a generic function that is used to operate both phase 0 and phase 1 structs. At some point, a developer makes a subtle change in that function because of the phase 1 spec update. Developer either forgets to branch the behaviour for phase 0, either thinks that the update have no effect for phase 0. The change was subtle enough that phase 0 regression tests *confirm* there is no regression.

My main motivation for code isolation is that phase 0 client after the fork is fully frozen. No more changes needed for both code and data (blocks etc.) on phase 0. So a *hard copy* makes sense comparing to some nicely DRY-ed approach (generics etc.). But I guess it will be clear how good is this approach only after trying it.
